We continue the scene-setting in this Second
Episode of At the Edge of the World.

49.14.text:
Last week, we noted that, in 1086, England's
first Norman king, William the Conqueror - who

56.24.text:
had reigned twenty years since his victory
at the Battle of Hastings - had made a survey

60.42.text:
of his kingdom of England, called Domesday
Book, which was intended to tell him everything

66.22.text:
about his people - their number, wealth, agriculture,
business, name of the lord of the manor - down

73.22.text:
to the smallest village, the last pig, the
last eel.

78.18.text:
We also discovered from the work of Mrs Jane
Cox at the National Archives, that some species

83.41.text:
of flora and fauna, that we take for granted,
were absent in Norman England.

87.79.text:
Here are some more absentees: there were no
blackbirds, delphiniums, marigolds, laburnum

95.03.text:
- those gorgeous, voluptuous effulgences of
yellow flowers that tell us that spring has

100.53.text:
really arrived. There was no lavender or rosemary.
Tobacco and drugs, including recreational

107.50.text:
drugs, like marijuana and cocaine, were not
available in Europe until the sixteenth century.

115.35.text:
There was little conception of medicine and
medical practice after the Fall of the Roman

119.06.text:
Empire in the West in the fifth century AD,
and the revival of Graeco-Roman medical knowledge

125.00.text:
by the Muslims in the Middle East, North Africa,
and Spain from the eighth century

130.56.text:

even thought wrong by some men in the Church

136.60.text:
who saw physical afflications as divine punishment
or as a test of their faith.

142.59.text:
Indeed, the whole of earthly life was a trial
in preparation for the Afterlife, and the

147.81.text:
brickbats of the Here and Now were to be borne
with equanimity.

151.43.text:
Priests, monks, and nuns sometimes wore hair
shirts, undertook self-flagellation, or became

158.77.text:
hermits living 'in the wild' on acorns, by
one account, their lives given to contemplation,

164.86.text:
prayer, and the mortiftion of the flesh.
Some hermits came together in groups, from

170.84.text:
which a religious foundation might evolve,

I wonder whether the folk who today own, or
stay in, hotels and restaurants called the

181.39.text:
'Something Hermitage' - a swanky sort of name
- know just what they are harking back to?

187.90.text:
Perhaps they do: teasmades in the bedroom
and amateur, inattentive, acne-faced waiters

193.33.text:
in the dining-room are the less attractive
modern equivalents of the hermit's cauldron

197.66.text:
of long-simmered soup made from root vegetables

203.94.text:
People knew that diseases, especially deseases
like plague, spread, but they had little idea

209.72.text:
of how to deal with it other than to try to
keep out of an area and burn the bodies after

214.42.text:
death.
There was no conception of infection from

217.84.text:
water, unless it smelt and looked particularly
unpleasant; or from cuts: really quite small

223.29.text: cuts could, and usually did, kill you.

227.21.text:
The idea of boiling water or sterilizing knives
in scalding water was only realized in the

232.51.text:
early nineteenth century. In his Memoires,
the Duc de Saint Simon, writing about the

238.27.text:
Court of Louis XIV at Versailles, that centre

244.65.text:
century, mentions that surgeons cleaned their
instruments once a month. We might wonder

It is very hard to know what life expectancy
was in Britain in these centuries. The 'common

257.51.text:
people' - as the masses were routinely described
by chroniclers - were of no interest other

262.23.text:
than as the number of men in an army, say,
or the bodies of the dead when a city was

267.25.text:
sacked, or stricken with plague.
The Bible speaks of 'three-score years and

272.28.text:
ten,' but this must have seemed as mythical
as the 969 years ascribed to Methuselah in

279.17.text:
the the Book of Genesis. We know a bit more
about the age of kings and clergymen, but

286.44.text:
Those who survived battle or the treatment
of their wounds by doctors might reach fifty,

291.16.text:
like King Alfred the Great. Some high clergy

297.26.text:
Consequently, people married much earlier
and, though there was no formal age of consent,

302.87.text:
twelve seems to have been the age at which
a marriage might be consumated, though it

306.79.text:
could be contracted much earlier.
Indeed, the age of consent set at sixteen

312.97.text:
in Britain was not, I think, established by

the people is not gathered until the later

324.54.text:
West as the political events of the century,

In the early years, among the elite, a growing
knowledge of the nameless masses was due to

336.37.text:
the work of private individuals and charitable

405.65.text:

411.13.text:
Governments also needed to know about the

421.32.text:

434.74.text:

439.53.text:

The Roman Empire took its year dates from

471.03.text:

476.25.text:
The annual calendar became important because
it marked festivals and feasts, when there

480.95.text:
might be free food, wine, games. For the political

487.27.text:

Two of our months are still named after Roman

493.43.text:

499.73.text:
The Church required to know the hours of the
day because the Offices had to be called,

504.68.text:

510.38.text:
in many Anglican churches whose bell-ringers
still summon the faithful to prayer or mark

515.88.text:
the sacrament of marriage.
The Church had sundials, but candle-clocks

520.82.text:
in our period were the most useful. A candle
was marked off by the hour as it burned down

526.38.text:
and, provided it was protected from draughts,
it was fairly efficient.

530.79.text:
A conception of time, learnt naturally by
everyone in any agrarian society, would have

536.76.text:
been the seasons of the year, an intuitive
knowledge that must surely go back to the

541.55.text:

did not know how old they were. #The idea

even in the writings of some of the educated

553.34.text:
in Britain, such as the early priestly chroniclers,
or other writers in the centuries after the

558.42.text:

century.

and our present century the twenty-first is

He devised a method of dating the years and

which he called anno domini - the Year of

Our Lord - the first year being Year One,

Christ, devised by St Bede at a monastery

Woodland was often measured in the number

Tracks or lanes might well have been established

Roads were, as they still are, determined

If water were shallow enough, a river or stream
